Our courses provide a rich learning experience that will allow you to develop critical business skills in areas such as business... Read more...
title: Introduction to Business Management
headline: This free online management course explains the Six Sigma principles used to drive profit and reduce waste in business.
description: This course explains how managers coordinate business activity to boost productivity. We explore the role of Six Sigma principles in driving business development and project management. Good managers can shorten the project life cycle and provide competitive strategy analysis to increase their company’s market share. We establish the value of such skills and provide the management training you need to boost productivity and move upward.

courseDescription:
Business managers are responsible for overseeing operations and assisting workers in maximising their levels of production. We begin this course by studying business management and identifying the role of business owners. We then examine business analysis and the role of the Six Sigma approach to project management.

The course then moves on to business development. We lay out the advantages and disadvantages of performing a ‘Strength, Weaknesses, Opportunities and Threats’ (SWOT) analysis. We provide an organisational view analysis of business processes and performance management, including performance, risk and cash management. The course establishes the benefits of tracking cash flow and investigating risk.

We explain the primary aspects of business management and provide practical ideas and structural foundations on which to build and continuously improve organisational practices. We lay out the legislation, principles and techniques relevant to business management and explain how to implement them in the workplace. Sign up for this business management training course to master Six Sigma principles and gain an edge over the competition.

Start Course Now
certificateDetail:
All Alison courses are free to enrol study and complete. To successfully complete this certificate course and become an Alison Graduate, you need to achieve 80% or higher in each course assessment. Once you have completed this certificate course, you have the option to acquire an official Diploma, which is a great way to share your achievement with the world.

Your Alison certificate is:
  • Ideal for sharing with potential employers
  • Include it in your CV, professional social media profiles and job applications.
  • An indication of your commitment to continuously learn, upskill & achieve high results.
  • An incentive for you to continue empowering yourself through lifelong learning.
Alison offers 3 types of Diplomas for completed Diploma courses:
  • Digital certificate: a downloadable certificate in PDF format immediately available to you when you complete your purchase.
  • certificate: a physical version of your officially branded and security-marked certificate, posted to you with FREE shipping.
  • Framed certificate: a physical version of your officially branded and security marked certificate in a stylish frame, posted to you with FREE shipping.
Start Course Now

All certificate are available to purchase through the Alison Shop. For more information on purchasing Alison certificate, please visit our FAQs. If you decide not to purchase your Alison certificate, you can still demonstrate your achievement by sharing your Learner Record or Learner Achievement Verification, both of which are accessible from your Dashboard. For more details on our certificate pricing, please visit our Pricing Page

modules.name: Module
modules.description: In this module, we will help you analyse what business management is. We will have the opportunity to explore the core concepts of business analysis. We will help you organise information related to the constraints of a project. You will have answers to questions like, "What is process measurement?" or "What is forecasting?"

modules.name: Module
modules.description: In this module, we will help you analyse effective listening skills. We will have the opportunity to explore the types of business environments. We will help you organise information related to organising the workplace. We will help you answer questions like: "What are some negotiation techniques?" or "What is the definition of human resources?"

slides:
• Business Management - Learning Outcomes

  • Having completed this module you will be able to:
    • Analyse the steps required to use business management.
    • Discuss what operations management is.
    • Describe how to identify the strategic analysis and product scope.
    • Explain business development and succession planning.
    • Discuss business process management.
    • Recognise planning and forecasting operations.
    • Summarise how to successfully manage cash and credit.

  • Business Management - Lesson Summary

  • Below you will find key information covered in this module:
    • The Business Analyst is a change agent. Business Analysis is a methodical strategy to initiating and managing change in organisations, whether they be for-profit enterprises, government agencies, or non-profit organisations.
    • Business analysis is utilised to discover and express the need for organisational change, as well as to assist such change. As business analysts, we determine and specify the solutions that will maximise the value an organisation delivers to its stakeholders.
    • The use of specialised knowledge, skills, tools, and processes to provide something of value to others is project management. Examples of projects include the creation of software for a better business process, the construction of a building, the rescue effort following a natural disaster, and the expansion of sales into a new geographic market.
    • The evolving nature of work as a result of technological advancements, globalisation, and other reasons means that work is increasingly structured around projects and teams are assembled depending on the abilities required to complete certain tasks.
    • Business development comprises activities and procedures designed to create and implement growth possibilities inside and between businesses. It is a subset of the business, commerce, and organisational theory disciplines. Customers, markets, and partnerships provide long-term value for a firm through business development. 

  • Business Management - Lesson Summary

  • Environment and Customer Service - Learning Outcomes

  • Having completed this module you will be able to:
    •  Analyse how to successfully use communication skills.
    • Discuss the various aspects of the business environment.
    • Describe the elements of organisational skills.
    • Explain how to utilise negotiation techniques.
    • Identify the aspects of human resources management.
    • Recognise the benefits of using customer service in business.
    • Summarise how to successfully use and understand time management.

  • Environment and Customer Service - Lesson Summary

  • Below you will find key information covered in this module:
    • Communication abilities enable you to both comprehend and be comprehended by others. These include, but are not limited to, successfully conveying ideas to others, actively listening during conversations, providing and accepting constructive feedback, and public speaking.
    • Active listening is the practice of paying attentive attention to the speaker. Active listeners are highly respected by their coworkers due to the attention and deference they show to others. Despite its apparent simplicity, this is a difficult talent to master and improve.
    • People are more inclined to respond to ideas offered with confidence in the workplace. There are several techniques to seem confident, such as making eye contact with the person you are addressing, sitting up straight with your shoulders relaxed, and preparing beforehand so that your thoughts are polished.
    • The business Environment is the sum or collection of all internal and external factors, including employees, customers' needs and expectations, supply and demand, management, clients, suppliers, owners, government activities, technological innovation, social and market trends, and economic changes, among others.
    • The business environment facilitates the identification of business prospects, the exploitation of relevant resources, the facilitation of firm planning, and the enhancement of the business's overall performance, growth, and profitability. There are several Business Environments kinds, including Micro environments and Macro environments.
